comment.author: 48761017@N07
comment._content:
Namoi was not a ferry she was a coastal passenger ship

NAMOI 1,416 gross tons, 809 net. Lbd: 245'2" x 31'6" x 21'7". Steel paddle steamer built by J Key & Sons, Kinghorn for the Hunter River New S N Co Ltd., Sydney. 2 funnels, compounded oscillating engine producing 350 horsepower. December 1884 transferred over to the Newcastle & Hunter River S N Co. Worked the Sydney - Hunter River route as a passenger - cargo vessel all her career. Placed in reserve 1923 with register closed in 1925 when she was hulked. Remains scuttled June 1933 off Sydney Heads

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48761017@N07] Thanks for the correction - our records have now been updated. The info on NAMOI also good for confirming the date as no later than 1925... Cheers!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I'm 70% convinced we also see Col. Alfred Spain in this pic. See comments here - www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8390574071/ Hey a couple of the gents aren't wearing collars and ties!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks for the suggestions Quasymody, its definately hard to get a clear pic of Alfred Spain's face - we have put the info away for a possible future confirmation! No collars & ties - perhaps NAMOI did not have a dress code!? ;)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The NAMOI left Sydney on Friday 30/12/1921, the day before the Regatta, so the overnight passengers had a good chance to get relaxed and comfortable! trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15964636

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=153536&amp... this SLNSW Sam Hood album includes a really good pic of Col. Spain taken at the 1937 Anniversary Regatta...see pic No. 12 (Spain is 2nd from the rhs...Justice Backhouse is also there)...just for interest...I've also discovered Col. Spain had two brothers who were also involved in sailing...Captain Stanley Spain, and Commander W.E. Spain...I hope they weren't identical triplets!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] He looks very very very similar! A little older and without a moustache, but the eyes are very similar. I will keep an eye out in the collection, we may have more of him that are unidentified. I think we can crack this one :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 56512128@N06
comment._content: Only 'Spain ' associtaed with Pittwater Regattas_ PITTWATER REGATTA. FLAG OFFICERS. Commodore Stuart F. Doyle. Vice-commodore John Roche, and Rear-commodore Stanley Spain have been appointed flag officers for the day for the Pittwater regatta, which will be held on December 30. They will be In charge of the flagship, the T.S.S. Gwydir, that day. Eight sailing races have been Included on the aquatic programme at this regatta. One which should be of particular Interest to Palm Beach is an event for big class yachts which will carry prizes presented by Palm Beach residents. The course of this race has been so arranged that the competing yachts will pass Palm Beach on four occasions. PITTWATER REGATTA. (1933, December 14). The Sydney Morning Herald (NSW : 1842 - 1954), p. 16. Retrieved from nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17032313
